title: 109_hr5001
content: The "Homeland Security Information Sharing Enhancement Act of 2006" is cited as the short title. Findings on dissemination of homeland security-related information are outlined in the act. Congress finds that the Department of Homeland Security has the authority to access, receive, and analyze law enforcement, intelligence, and other information to detect terrorist threats. The Department is also empowered to ensure timely access to this information to fulfill its information sharing responsibilities. The Director of National Intelligence is prohibited from directly disseminating information to State and local government officials. The National Counterterrorism Center supports the Department of Homeland Security in disseminating terrorism information. The Department of Homeland Security is responsible for sharing analyzed information with other Federal, State, and local agencies for homeland security purposes. The Department of Homeland Security is responsible for sharing law enforcement-related information and establishing secure communication infrastructure to prevent and respond to terrorist attacks. The Homeland Security Advisory System is being amended to include a new section (SEC. 203) in the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The Under Secretary for Information and Analysis is required to implement a Homeland Security Advisory System to provide public advisories and alerts on threats to homeland security. The System must include information on protective measures, limit alerts to specific regions or sectors at risk, and not use color designations exclusively. The Homeland Security Advisory System must provide advisories and alerts on threats, including information on protective measures. It should not exclusively use color designations for specifying threat conditions. Sec. 204 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 further amends the Homeland Security Information Sharing provisions. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 amends information sharing provisions by integrating and standardizing intelligence information within the Department. Designated officers coordinate systems for gathering and disseminating homeland security information from various sources. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis establishes procedures for reviewing and analyzing information from various sources. Feedback mechanisms are developed to provide information to State, local, tribal, and private-sector entities. Training opportunities are provided to Department employees to enhance their understanding of intelligence. The Under Secretary for Intelligence and Analysis evaluates how employees utilize homeland security information and participate in the Department's information sharing environment. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. Sec. 205 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 establishes a Comprehensive Information Technology Network Architecture. The Secretary will establish a comprehensive information technology network architecture for the Office of Intelligence and Analysis, incorporating features of the SHARE Network proposed by the Markle Foundation. This architecture is defined as an integrated framework for evolving existing IT and acquiring new technology to achieve strategic goals and information resources. The Secretary will establish a comprehensive information technology network architecture for the Office of Intelligence and Analysis to achieve strategic goals and information resources management goals. A clerical amendment will be made to the table of contents in the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a report within 360 days outlining a plan to implement a comprehensive information technology network architecture for the Office of Intelligence and Analysis as required by the Homeland Security Act of 2002. The report must include priorities for developing the information technology network architecture, how the components will interconnect, technology challenges, and options. The report should include technology options, security protections, safeguards for civil liberties and privacy, and an operational best practices plan for the comprehensive information technology network architecture. The Secretary of Homeland Security must submit a progress report on developing the comprehensive information technology network architecture required by the Homeland Security Act of 2002. Additionally, the Intelligence Component is defined in the Act. The Security Act of 2002 is amended to define the term 'intelligence component of the Department' as any entity within the Department of Homeland Security that deals with homeland security information, excluding certain security programs. SEC. 5. AUTHORITY FOR DISSEMINATING HOMELAND SECURITY-RELATED INFORMATION. Amendment to Title I of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to include new section 104 granting authority for disseminating homeland security-related information. The Secretary or designee is responsible for sharing terrorist threat information with State, local, tribal officials, and the private sector. Federal officials need approval to issue homeland security-related alerts, except in urgent situations or when assisting law enforcement. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include items related to a specific title. The table of contents in the Act is amended to include items related to a specific title, including "Sec. 104. Authority for disseminating homeland security-related information."
